results.name: Generalized Pascal triangle associated with the set of primes.
comment: Given a subset S of the integers Z, Bhargava has shown how to associate with S a generalized factorial function, denoted n!_S, sharing many properties of the classical factorial function n! (which corresponds to the choice S = Z). In particular, he shows that the generalized binomial coefficients n!_S/(k!_S*(n-k)!_S) are always integral for any choice of S.
Here we take S = {2,3,5,7,...} the set of primes.

The generalized factorial n!_S is given by the formula n!_S = product {primes p} (p^(floor(n/(p-1)) + floor(n/(p^2-p)) + floor(n/(p^3-p^2)) + ...), and appears in the database as n!_S = A053657(n) for n>=1. We make the convention that 0!_S = 1.
See A186432 for the generalized Pascal triangle associated with the set
link: M. Bhargava, The factorial function and generalizations, Amer. Math. Monthly, 107(2000), 783-799.
formula: T(n,k) = A053657(n)/(A053657(k)*A053657(n-k)), for n,k >= 0, with the convention that A053657(0) = 1.
maple: #Uses program for A053657 written by _Peter Luschny_
A053657 := proc(n) local P, p, q, s, r;
for p in P do s := 0; q := p-1;
do if q > (n-1) then break fi;
s := s + iquo(n-1, q); q := q*p; od;
r := r * p^s; od; r end:
mathematica: b[n_] := Product[p^Sum[Floor[(n - 1)/((p - 1) p^k)], {k, 0, n}], {p, Prime[ Range[n]]}];
